terms.definition: The main civil code of Germany that contains family law provisions, including custody and contact rights.
terms.context: References like 'BGB §1626' refer to specific sections of the German Civil Code.

terms.definition: The court responsible for family law matters, including custody and contact orders. Usually part of the Amtsgericht (local court).
terms.context: You file custody and contact applications at the Familiengericht in your area.

terms.definition: Local government office that provides support, counseling, and mediation services for families. Can help with custody matters and contact arrangements.
terms.context: The Jugendamt offers free counseling and can help mediate custody and contact disputes.

terms.definition: When both parents share decision-making rights and responsibilities for their child.
terms.context: Married parents automatically have gemeinsame Sorge. Unmarried parents can establish it through a joint declaration or court application.

terms.definition: A court order that sets out when and how a parent (or other person) can have contact with a child.
terms.context: If contact is being blocked, you can apply to the Familiengericht for an Umgangsregelung.

terms.definition: The right of a parent (or other person) to have contact with a child. Protected by law.
terms.context: Under BGB §1684, children have the right to contact with both parents, and parents have the right and duty to have contact with their child.

terms.definition: A formal declaration by a man that he is the father of a child. Required for unmarried fathers to have parental rights.
terms.context: Paternity acknowledgment typically happens at the Standesamt or Jugendamt before or after the child's birth.

terms.definition: A joint declaration by unmarried parents to establish joint custody. Can be signed at the Jugendamt or Standesamt.
terms.context: For unmarried parents, a Sorgeerklärung can establish gemeinsame Sorge without going to court.

terms.definition: The lowest level of court in Germany. Family matters are handled by the Familiengericht division of the Amtsgericht.
terms.context: You file custody and contact applications at the Amtsgericht in your city or district.

terms.definition: Local government office that handles civil registration, including birth certificates, marriages, and paternity acknowledgments.
terms.context: You can acknowledge paternity or sign custody declarations at the Standesamt.

terms.definition: A formal decision or order issued by a court, especially in family law matters.
terms.context: A Beschluss from the Familiengericht can change custody arrangements or set contact schedules.

terms.definition: A formal court judgment, typically after a full hearing. More formal than a Beschluss.
terms.context: An Urteil is a final court decision, while a Beschluss is often an interim or procedural order.

terms.definition: The central principle in German family law. All custody and contact decisions must prioritize the child's welfare.
terms.context: Courts always consider Kindeswohl when making decisions about custody and contact.

terms.definition: When only one parent has custody rights and decision-making authority for the child.
terms.context: Sole custody is only granted in exceptional circumstances, such as when the other parent is unable to care for the child.

terms.definition: A process where a neutral third party helps parents reach an agreement about custody or contact arrangements.
terms.context: Many Jugendämter offer free or low-cost mediation services to help parents resolve disputes without going to court.
